hello and welcome to black hat europe 2020 a virtual event this continues to be
an unprecedented year with many new challenges the critical work you all do to secure
our digital world is more important now than ever and bringing all of you the black cat
community together to discuss the latest security research trends and best practices is vital
while our event is entirely on this sheet online this year the black hat team and review board have
made every effort to provide you with the same high standard of black hat content to help you
this includes a full lineup of black cat trainings and it includes 40 black hat briefings
over 18 tracks covering the latest security research from the global community
outside of our trainings and our briefings programs we have a wide variety of content that is available to
all attendees we have over 30 open source tools being demonstrated in the blackhead arsenal
and we have many sessions on current trends and best practices being presented by our sponsors
and our partners our keynotes and our review board lock notes are also open to
all attendees we have a packed agenda with the best content and we hope you enjoy your time
with us it's now my pleasure to welcome jeff moss to provide his opening remarks
in addition to founding both black hat and defcon jeff has served as vice president and chief security officer at
icann he is an advisor with the us homeland security advisory council and a commissioner with the global
council on the stability of cyberspace please join me in welcoming the dark tangent jeff
moss welcome to day one of black hat europe 2020 our first
virtual event i'm jeff moss founder of black hat and it's going to be my privilege
to introduce our day one keynote speaker pete cooper before i do that i'm just going to talk
a little bit about different communities in our space how i see them overlapping and where the
role of researchers and hackers infosec collide create tension
with government and what we can do about that so first off i see there's primarily
four actors in our space we have organized criminals mostly interested in how to make the most
amount of money at the least amount of risk and you can see this trend with the way they're approaching ransomware
second we've got governments now governments are not monolithic they're not as single-minded as a
organized crime group because they have a lot of different competing interests inside one part maybe the intelligence agencies
are interested in verifying that other governments of the world are doing what they say they're doing
and to verify this they may perform some clandestine online operations to steal some secrets is north korea
really complying with an arms control is iran doing something it shouldn't be doing right that's traditional
clandestine operations but on the domestic front on the policy front we see governments pursuing a
handful of different agendas right to repair is it legal or not legal are you allowed to hack
your own tv what's the liability for an iot device that bursts into flame
biomedical liability for an implantable medical device there's a lot of unanswered questions
right now and where are the answers to some of these policy debates coming from well companies
a third community they are manufacturing the product they're the ones that have built the infrastructure they're generally
interested in maximizing return minimizing disruption minimizing regulation
and minimizing embarrassment they're the experts that built the product so they're the ones that are mostly one
seen in front of government lobbying to change a law at a law and then the fourth community which i
think of myself is belonging to the academic hacker and security researcher community
we're the ones that are really interested in trying to figure out how does this product work what does it really do
underneath the surface is it doing what the manufacturers claim and if it's not we want to tell the
world about it and through this kind of very energized
cyclical process we've come up with disclosure which led into commercial bug money programs right we act as sort of a
a third party a neutral third party telling policy makers what is and isn't possible and this
leads to tension a tension between the researcher community and government
on one hand government really wants to understand what's possible they need another voice to tell them something different that's not
coming from the lobbyists but on the other hand if the way you're coming up with that information
maybe violating copyright that might be uh not acceptable right you can't
legislate based on stolen information maybe so what do we do about this
we have historically moved more and more into the realm of policy if you look at the trajectory of hackers
and infosec over the last five to ten years we are now providing that information policy makers have grown up with
technology and computers and they're asking us our opinion this is a really dangerous time for us right
now on one hand because they're finally asking us our opinion so great opportunity great risk though
is they're asking us our opinion and if we screw this up we may not be taken seriously
so it's very important that the community of the infosec researcher the community of government we learn
from each other and we learn how to work through this tension right governments have been around for
hundreds thousands of years these technology researchers were pretty new and we're not steeped in the ways of
sort of this political navigation and so we need to be cut a little slack but we also don't
need to be guided and shown how to properly get the most out of our knowledge shared with
policymakers and that's why i find this keynote so interesting so it's now my honor to
introduce pete cooper day one keynote who's a deputy director cyber defense in the uk cabinet office

turned to cyber operations advisor he also was the first to create in 2016 the uk's
multidisciplinary cyber strategy competition integrating a competition within the uk community
he's known for leading security change across the aerospace sector his specialty
but also with work across the industry private and government sectors so he's a pretty
big view of how security influences government private
but for me my first interaction with pete was at defcon you may not realize this but but pete
created and ran the defcon aerospace village really making aerospace technology
accessible average kids hackers researchers could get our hands on avionic systems
and with helping hand with some guidance he really helped foster a global community now three
years old right it's gotten its own legs under itself and is really helping to try to improve

work through our challenges to reduce risks to our societies so it's my privilege
pete take it away good morning uh welcome to black hat europe
for me hacking as a mindset trying to understand how something really works finding ways of improving it being

and now i'm starting the next phase as i'm taking up the role of deputy director cyber defence in the government security group within

aerospace village at defcon jeff you might also know as dark tangent
asked me to come and talk about the journey as i'm starting back at the government and what shaped my thinking as i start
my next chapter the government security group is led by
the government chief security officer the gcso and the mission is a critical one we enable government to protect citizens
and provide vital public services by understanding and managing the security risks
by overseeing the day-to-day operations in support of security across a whole of government including the response to serious and
across the environmental security incidents as you can see from the scope and this
is a snapshot of some of the scope that we look at there's a huge variety of critical organizations and services we cover
beard across a huge number of civil servants and services that they're looking after whether it's buildings an estate and the
amount of professionals that we have doing the job and it's set out in four pillars it's
set out in physical looking after the physical security of buildings and all the services and
assets technical really looking after the the key technical aspects
personnel to look after the personnel within the business and i'm also honored to lead the cyber insurance team in the
government security group which looks after the government sector of the national cyber security program so that's all the policies the strategy
the standards into response to the government red team and much more but like most people in the industry i've not had a straight
path to this role and it's been a huge learning journey at every stage rewinding the clock so the 80s were
great this was my first um we called a computer i'd probably call it a
raspberry pi for old people they had a luxurious 16k of ram and
coding was something that you did because it would take about 10 minutes of listening to the tape loading your program to find out that it hadn't
actually worked so it was a great start to actually understanding some of the technology
and around that time we also had some great hacker movies starting to come out and a lot of
my thinking was shaped by um films such as wargames and about how to actually start looking at looking at problems and digging into
um what the art the possible was but then top gun happened and like a cat with a
laser pointer i was off and after a lot of training i ended up
as instructing the tornado ground attack fast jet aircraft having done quite a few operations along the way and when looking at something
sharp and pointy it's really easy to get focused on the cool stuff but running around at 100 feet at low
level is amazing going up against a massive adversity air package in a large exercise is amazing and
that's the cool stuff but behind that is the time spent learning the basics
and building apps and building those key critical skills because you've got to learn how to fly
and do the fundamentals every single time without thinking about it before you learn how to fight
and the fundamentals have to become second nature so that irrespective of what the
adversary throws at you you've got to be able to keep being able to do the fundamentals
basics such as being able to do night air to review fueling as an amazing skill but it took practice to get it
right so you could do it every single time even if you had the occasional miss because sometimes if you couldn't tank
you couldn't actually contribute to the operation so it all starts getting complicated or going wrong it's your ability to do the
fundamentals without thinking that are going to keep you moving forward and doing the right thing
and across cyber security it's really easy to get excited and distracted about the latest sharp and pointy thing but being able to
do the fundamentals of managing cyber security risk protecting against attacks detecting
those attacks and minimizing their impact are the basics that enables absolutely everything else
and as much as the tornado might look really advanced there was always something out there that was way more advanced
faster could fly higher and with much better kit but not at any stage did we ever turn
around and say our success was going to be defined by who had the best kit and the best technology
because as much as technology is a huge part of what we use both in flying and also cyber security
we aren't going to technology our way through and out of our challenges because winning losing isn't defined by
our technology is defined by our thinking we need to actually get through our challenges by
challenging our thinking and that will allow us to actually um defend against our adversaries and we
see that with the adversaries in that success and failure isn't about that technology they don't have access
to alien technology that we don't we've all fundamentally got the same underlying technology
much of the time success is about understanding our risks opportunities and knowing our strengths and weaknesses
and how to manage them if our adversaries know our strengths and weaknesses of our technology better
than we do then you're going to have a bad day it's our thinking that allows us to make the most of our technology
one of the other key things that we also did in in the aviation world and it's the lessons that i've rolled into the cyber world is
that when a new aircraft comes into service it'll be thrown at a whole bunch of independent and objective test pilots
who are going to take it through its paces and really find out what would happen if their role and task is to challenge the
assumptions discover what works discover what doesn't work and really explore the
envelope of what's safe and find the edge cases of how the users can potentially get themselves into trouble
and then really understand those risks and once they understand those risks and
that they discover that they're appropriate they they give it the okay to be brought into service
and we see a lot of that in cyber security bringing in new systems or services our users aren't cyber test pilots and
we need to make sure that everything is secure out of the box and with great instructions about how to keep it and them safe and secure
but it's not enough to just do that because we also got to communicate about those risks and make sure the users know where the
educators are and what they can do to keep themselves safe and once we've communicated about that
risk then we need to be able to build trust in that system because you really know that system and
know how it's going to work and then that is the key element of
right at the very start of getting everything right but even with that and even with making the aircraft as safe as possible
even with the right processes the user can still accidentally get it wrong
human nature will always catch us out this is one of the early training aircraft i trained on initially
so single engine ejector seat lots of safety systems lots of procedures to keep you safe
check and cross-check and uh standby systems but i still managed to make a mistake where i
accidentally started shutting down my own engine which isn't the best thing to do when
you're flying in a single engine aircraft it was human error that i recognized fairly straight away because the engine
started slowing down and it was all starting to go wrong horribly i undid what i did and bless the
aircraft and dug me out the poo the system was designed to keep me safe and i managed to make a mistake
but the training and the resilience built into the system got me back to normal apart from my heart rate defence in
depth is critical in both flying and also cyber defense
because it's key to remember that things will go wrong users will click links back end team could potentially
set up a service incorrectly and that resilience is going to stretch across the people the process
and the technology and you've got to design them down to design them down a secure path without
technology being designed to fail safe and you can only really gain confidence in your resilience if you train
and exercise your people your processes and your technology and that will give you the confidence
that no matter what's thrown at you you can get yourself back to a safe state and a secure state
and then also what makes a great flight it's really easy to get distracted by the fast and the pointy
but it's the exercise the enterprise behind it that really makes it fly so supply chain the manufacturers the
services the engineers those are all the key elements that made the whole thing work and it's exactly
the same when it comes to cyber security and having great and resilient organizations the the full foundations of that are
based around having a fantastic supply chain that you can work with having manufacturers across hardware and
software having services that are you're able to really work with fantastically well
and then engineers that can pull it together and much much more and it's easy to forget about that when
we're looking at the sharp and pointy thing on the coalface but everything we've got has got some
element of risk aviation had a really huge accident rates until
the sector really started digging into the culture and understanding of what was causing those accidents
and it absolutely transformed safety flight safety culture was key in helping
drive risk down to as low as reasonably practical as part of that role i was a flight
safety officer in the air force which allowed me to actually really understand and learn
about all of the key risks that were around the organization and as part of that people could come to
me and chat about whether whether formerly informally confidentially or not to resist risks and issues all the way through to
the top of the organization and we always think about the incident because the incidents get the headlines
but it's the events the near misses the problems all of that stuff that's happening underneath the surface is all of the
activity and stuff that will actually help you predict where your incidents are going to happen
and that's exactly the same when it comes to how we're defending ourselves across cyber security is that the more that we understand
what's happening below the surface helps us better understand and predict where those incidents are going to happen so we can prevent them
but we can only start doing that in an appropriate culture and for this um a lot of the reading and
research i've done previously was around james reason who did a huge amount of great research in safety culture and
that it's all equally applicable into cyber security and what he talked about was the fact that to have a great engaged culture
it really started off with a reporting culture an organizational climate where people can readily report problems errors and
near-misses but it can be really hard to put your hand up to error but that's why you really need
a just culture where personnel can understand the boundary between acceptable and unacceptable behavior
and are willing to report those errors or potential errors or those near misses or those problems because that's where you really start
getting the value but if your organization and your team are raising these issues
then you need to have a flexible culture our adversaries evolve and therefore we have to as well
security isn't a static task we need that flexibility at both the technical and organizational
layers to respond to our challenges and when we've actually started looking
at those challenges we need to have a learning culture so that it's more than just fixing it but also understanding why and how
something happened so that we can change and adapt all the way through and really the final keystone of that
culture is that questioning culture empowering individuals to speak up if they see risks mitigations or
opportunities and if they think something isn't right even if they don't know the solution it's really important to hear their
voice and all of this brings the power of the
individual to the organization when it comes to cyber security
it really brings a key level of understanding what your risks are and it helps to be able to help you identify and drive it down
but it's more than that because when we talk about culture we always think about people but it's the culture that's going to
really help you gain that unique risk insight across all of your data at scale
and pace and move beyond the stove pipes we often see in cyber security
so one of the amazing things about being in the air force at the time was

camaraderie community that they were looking at and actually growing across defcon it was just different domains and it was
a huge eye-opener to me and actually really started me back on that technical path
another thing that really stood out at that time as well and we've got we it's trying not to be really careful with language
which is a pilot is just a pilot if that pilot is attacking you then their class is your adversary
if the pilot isn't attacking you then they're likely an ally and then you treat them as such shooting down friendly forces is a really uncool thing
to do and when it comes to the terminology around hackers a hacker is just a hacker
and it depends how you class yourself whether it's a research or researcher or not but that terminology doesn't necessarily

together but then taking those experiences and
learning more about what collaboration really meant i did a tour supporting joint ops where i'd be in as the air
advisor working with all the ground forces and all the other air forces hugely international multi-domain with
different languages units capabilities priorities and making life critical decisions every single day
to communicate you need to be able to communicate sorry to collaborate you needed to communicate
and that wasn't just technical because we're separated by more than just our languages our specialisms and our moral
we all have diverse perspectives on what our challenges are and we all have our individual horizons
and the real value of collaboration comes through seeing the world through those diverse perspectives
because by doing that you then start creating shared perspectives and you start pushing out your joint
horizons so you can see further and develop a much better joint understanding of everything
and once you start having that joint horizon and once you start having those shared perspectives understanding
it transforms how you see risk it transforms how you can actually use the resources and the actions you
can achieve from them it creates a unique collaboration so you can identify those opportunities and
ideas that you would not have been able to do previously and that's what it really means to collaborate and if we look across
everything we're doing in cyber security be that in organizations be that in the
defensive teams or the offensive teams or internationally it's how we collaborate together across
all of our partners that makes a difference and seeing the world through diverse perspectives
and in collaborating across those diverse teams as i've said the best solutions are those joint solutions
and it takes that collaboration an orchestra is made up of different sections strings woodwind
brass and percussion but if you want to create a symphony every single element is woven together
no one section can do it by itself but it does need a bit of structure it's difficult to scale a jamming
session without a losing rhythm and becoming a cacophony and also while we're here let's talk a little bit about the imposter syndrome
just because we can't play the violin doesn't mean that we should feel like an imposter if we're playing in the same orchestra
it's possible to appreciate and really understand the artistry but we all bring and play to our
strengths and bring something different and it's how we actually bring that harmony together
because the best technology in the world needs the best policy and strategy to support it and bring it forwards and get

together that makes the difference so when we talk about the the challenges of getting policy and technical to work

and the people that you have in those teams are ultimately the critical enabler to all

for the next generation coming forwards i was honored to have founded the uk's

and key to this is building bridges across all of those communities when we look across our challenges in

to be underpinning all of it which is trust and that trust is going to be the thing

ever on orbit ctf involving a satellite aircraft
industry and it shows that actually with not much in the way of resource or

lots of people across both the private and public sector pitched in to make a huge difference as

around the uk and europe on a voluntary basis pulling together a huge amount of diverse

in nine different languages analyzed thousands of ips and i identified and helped on hundreds of critical vulnerabilities
when we talk about building passion time and when we talk about taking things

should give huge thanks to them and everybody that's made such a difference in the battle against kovic 19
because across especially in the cyber domain it's innovation like this that makes such a difference
and really in bringing it all together there are so many similarities across

so thank you very much i really look forward to my next chapter and everybody else's
